column7: will grow heavier and more costly.”

column1: Macron now faces the task of steering France out of its financial morass.
Why do French governments keep collapsing?

The chaos can be traced back to Macron’s dramatic decision to call a snap poll last year. Piqued by the remarkable successes of the far-right National Rally (RN) in the European elections in June 2024
column2: the president rolled the dice on a parliamentary vote. The gamble backfired and his centrist bloc lost seats to the far right and far left
column3: leaving France with a divided National Assembly and effectively ungovernable.

column1: French President Emmanuel Macron casts his ballot flanked by first lady Brigitte Macron at a polling station on July 7
column2: 2024. Mohammed Badra/Reuters

column1: But it didn’t have to be this way. France’s Fifth Republic
column2: founded by President Charles de Gaulle in 1958
column3: was designed to end the chronic instability that had plagued the Third and Fourth Republics earlier in the 20th century. The new constitution gave broad powers to the executive and set up a majority system to avoid short-lived governments. As a result
column4: for decades
column5: two mainstream political parties on the left and right alternated in power.

column1: Macron blew up that order in 2017
column2: by becoming the first president elected without the backing of either of the main established parties. Re-elected in 2022
column3: he soon lost his parliamentary majority as voters flocked to the extremes. Two years of fragile rule followed
column4: with Macron repeatedly forced to invoke Article 49.3 of the constitution – pushing legislation through without a vote
column5: to the increasing displeasure of opposition lawmakers and much of the French public.

column1: In the 2024 snap election
column2: the left won most seats in the second round of voting but still fell short of a majority after the far right dominated the first. But the left’s hopes of forming a minority government collapsed when Macron refused to accept their choice of prime minister. Unlike Germany or Italy
column3: France has no tradition of coalition building
column4: instead its politics have been shaped for more than 60 years by a presidency-dominated system.

column1: What will Macron do next?
There’s a French saying that goes “Les mêmes causes produisent les mêmes effets” – the same causes produce the same consequences. And for Macron
column2: history does indeed risk repeating itself unless he can find a prime minister able to broker compromise.

column1: The problem is that
column2: after three failed centrist prime ministers whose tenures ranged from between three to nine months
column3: the opposition parties are in no mood to give another one a chance.

column1: So Macron is caught in a political vise
column2: with the far left calling for his resignation
column3: the far right demanding a snap election and the mainstream left and right remain unable to reach consensus.

column1: Who could take over next and will it matter?
The frontrunner to replace Bayrou appears to be outgoing Defense Minister Sébastien Lecornu. But by choosing a premier from his own ranks Macron risks sounding tone-deaf
column2: a sign that he has yet to fully accept the reality of his snap election defeat.

column1: Sébastien Lecornu arrives at the Élysée Palace in Paris on Sunday. Tom Nicholson/Getty Images

column2: the same compromise that Bayrou used to push through this year’s budget with concessions to the left. Yet that path now looks unworkable.

column3: but not at any price.

column2: including his effort to forgive student loans. The court repeatedly relied on the “major questions doctrine” to trim the power of the White House and federal agencies to act without congressional approval.

column1: The federal law at issue allows a president to “regulate … importation” during emergencies
column2: but the statute does not specifically address tariffs.

column1: The law “bestows significant authority on the president to undertake a number of actions in response to a declared national emergency
column2: ” the appeals court wrote in its decision. “But none of these actions explicitly include the power to impose tariffs
column3: duties
column4: or the like
column5: or the power to tax.”

column1: While the bulk of the tariffs Trump imposed during his second term could ultimately be unwound by the court’s decision
column2: the president has other levers he can pull to continue pushing his tariff-heavy agenda.

column1: Sectoral tariffs Trump has imposed during his second term – most recently a 50% tariff on derivatives of steel and aluminum
column2: such as spray deodorants and baby strollers – have relied on a different law
column3: known as Section 232.

column1: The Section 232 authority gives the president the authority to impose higher tariffs on national security grounds. But it can only be used to target specific sectors and requires an investigation to be launched before tariffs can be imposed.

column3: they too have catches that could make it harder for him to dangle and then withdraw duties quickly
